tidysq 1.0
  • Reference

Count k-mers in sequences

Source: R/kmers.R
count_kmers.Rd

Counts all k-mers or position-specific k-mers present in the input sequence(s).

count_kmers(sq, lens = 0, dists = list(0), alph = NULL,
  position = FALSE)

Arguments

sq

a vector or matrix describing sequence(s).
lens

integer vector of lengths of k-mers.
dists

integer vector of distances between elements of k-mer (0 means consecutive elements). See Details.
alph

integer, numeric or character vector of all possible elements of the alphabet.
position

logical, if TRUE position-specific k-mers are counted.

Value

a simple_triplet_matrix where columns represent k-mers and rows sequences. See Details for specifics of the naming convention.

Details

ns vector and ds vector must have equal length. Elements of ds vector are used as equivalents of d parameter for respective values of ns. For example, if ns is c(4, 4, 4), the ds must be a list of length 3. Each element of the ds list must have length 3 or 1, as appropriate for a d parameter in count_ngrams function.

A dists vector should be always n - 1 in length. For example when n = 3, d = c(1,2) means A_A__A. For n = 4, d = c(2,0,1) means A__AA_A. If vector d has length 1, it is recycled to length n - 1.

k-mer names follow a specific convention and have three parts for position-specific k-mers and two parts otherwise. The parts are separated by _. The . symbol is used to separate elements within a part. The general naming scheme is POSITION_KMER_DISTANCE. The optional POSITION part of the name indicates the actual position of the k-mer in the sequence(s) and will be present only if pos = TRUE. This part is always a single integer. The KMER part of the name is a sequence of elements in the k-mer. For example, 4.2.2 indicates the k-mer 422 (e.g. TCC). The DISTANCE part of the name is a vector of distance(s). For example, 0.0 indicates zero distances (continuous k-mers), while 1.2 represents distances for the k-mer A_A__A.

Examples of k-mer names:

  • 46_4.4.4_0.1 : trigram 44_4 on position 46

  • 12_2.1_2 : bigram 2__1 on position 12

  • 8_1.1.1_0.0 : continuous trigram 111 on position 8

  • 1.1.1_0.0 : continuous trigram 111 without position information

Note

By default, the counted k-mer data is stored in a memory-saving format. To convert an object to a 'classical' matrix use the as.matrix function. See examples for further information.

See also

Extract k-mers from sequence(s): extract_kmers.

Examples

set.seed(1410)
random_sqs <- random_sq(5, 20, type = "nuc", is_clean = TRUE)

# count 1-mers without position information for nucleotides
count_kmers(random_sqs, 1, 0, alph = c("A", "C", "G", "T"), pos = FALSE)
#> A 5x4 simple triplet matrix.

# count position-specific 3-mers from multiple nucleotide sequences
kmers <- count_kmers(random_sqs, 3, c(0, 0, 0),
                     alph = c("A", "C", "G", "T"), pos = TRUE)

# output results of the k-mer counting to screen
as.matrix(kmers)

# count multiple k-mers of different lengths and distances
count_kmers(random_sqs, c(1, 2, 2), list(0, 0, 1),
            alph = c("A", "C", "G", "T"), pos = FALSE)
#> A 5x36 simple triplet matrix.
